snippet: Facing criticism from religious-affiliated institutions, the Obama administration promised on Tuesday to explore ways to make a new health insurance requirement more flexible.
abstract: Obama administration is seeking to ease mounting objections to a new rule that would require health insurance plans, including those offered by Catholic universities and charities, to offer birth control to women free of charge; administration officials promise to explore ways to make it more palatable to religious-affiliated institutions, reacting to vocal opposition from religious leaders and an escalating political fight.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

lead_paragraph: Facing criticism from religious-affiliated institutions, the Obama administration promised on Tuesday to explore ways to make a new health insurance requirement more flexible.

headline.seo: Obama Addresses Ire on Health Insurance Contraception Rule
headline.main: Obama Tries to Ease Ire on Contraception Rule
headline.print_headline: Obama Tries to Ease Ire on Contraception Rule
